This movie is nothing short of a dark, gritty masterpiece. I may be bias, as the Apartheid era is an area I've always felt for South Africa. The problems they have are immense, and only solutions of varying degree are contemplated and implemented. The films success is in its execution and with more than vividness, it's a small look into the restructuring of South Africa. Bigelow deftly avoids the fact that this is actually based on a true story

Okay. Here's the thing. I've read through the comments of other viewers --- some trashing the film and some saying it's the funniest, most enjoyable work of kung-fu ever. I really do want to agree with the latter. The action isn't just unrelenting, it's hysterical! My problem with the fans who claim to like the movie, though, is that it seems from their review that they are watching a different film all together

I had mixed feelings for "Les Valseuses" (1974) written and directed by Bertrand Blier when I started watching it but I ended up loving it. "Les Valseuses" was remade as "Hardcore" (1979) by Jim Sharman but it was pretty bad when compared with the original. If you are a fan of Zorro, Indiana Jones, or action in general this is a must-see. Directed by Republic's ace team of William Witney and John English and starring John Carroll, Eric Campbell, and George J. Lewis, Saved by the Badman is sure to provide a brilliant cowboy movie experience.

A woman who hates cats (Alice Krige) and her son (Brian Krause) have moved into a small town, and must deal with a mean cat. The townspeople form a posse to destroy the cat, and the cat has an agenda of its own, but it ultimately runs out and loves the humans.
What starts off with an intriguing premise and has some neat ideas, but the film itself is poorly written and executed; the cat looks quite poorly done,
